description: Moving from a medical 'disorder' model to a 'condition' model based on neurodiversity.

resources.Language & Impact:
Condition vs. Disorder

Shifting the focus from what is 'broken' to how the brain is 'wired' differently.

  • The Power of Words: Using 'Condition' (condici√≥n) instead of 'Disorder' (trastorno) to reduce stigma.
  • The OS Analogy: An autistic brain is like a different operating system (e.g., Mac vs. Windows). Neither is broken; they simply require different software to function.
  • The Spectrum: Autism is not a linear scale, but a diverse range of unique profiles.

description: How the environment and internal signals (interoception) impact the student's ability to learn.

resources.Beyond the Five Senses:
Interoception & Sensory Load

Sensory processing is the foundation of classroom behaviour.

  • Interoception: The internal sense that signals hunger, thirst, and the need for the toilet. Autistic students may not feel these signals until they are urgent.
  • The Pressure Cooker: Sensory overload (lights, noise, textures) builds up like steam. A 'meltdown' is the resulting explosion, not a choice.
  • Monotropism: A deep, tunnel-like focus. Interrupting this 'flow' can be physically and mentally jarring.

description: Moving from abstract instructions to concrete, direct communication.

resources.Communication Cheat Sheet:
Phrasing for Success

Neurotypical communication is often full of 'polite' ambiguity. Autistic students thrive on precision.

Avoid This (Vague)Try This (Concrete)
'Would you like to start your work?''Open your book to page 10.'
'Keep an eye on the clock.''We will finish in five minutes.'
'Pull yourself together.''I see you are overwhelmed. Go to the quiet area.'
'Everyone, listen up!''[Name], I am giving the instructions now.'
